009package imagingbook.common.geometry.fitting.ellipse.algebraic;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
012
013import java.util.Arrays;
014
015import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
016import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
017import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealVector;
018
019import ij.IJ;
020import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
021import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.PntUtils;
022import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
023import imagingbook.common.math.eigen.EigenDecompositionJama;
024
025/**
026 * <p>
027 * Algebraic ellipse fit based on Fitzgibbon's method [1], numerically improved
028 * as suggested by Halir and Flusser [2]. See [3, Sec. 11.2.1] for a detailed
029 * description. Note: This implementation performs data centering or,
030 * alternatively, accepts a specific reference point. Capable of performing an
031 * (exact) 5-point fit!
032 * </p>
033 * <p>
034 * [1] A. W. Fitzgibbon, M. Pilu, and R. B. Fisher. Direct least- squares
035 * fitting of ellipses. IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine
036 * Intelligence 21(5), 476-480 (1999). <br>
037 * [2] R. Halíř and J. Flusser. Numerically stable direct least squares fitting
038 * of ellipses. In "Proceedings of the 6th International Conference in Central
039 * Europe on Computer Graphics and Visualization (WSCG’98)", pp. 125-132, Plzeň,
040 * CZ (February 1998). <br>
041 * [3] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
042 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
043 * </p>
044 * 
045 * @author WB
046 * @version 2021/11/06
047 */
048public class EllipseFitFitzgibbonStable implements EllipseFitAlgebraic {
049        
050        private static final RealMatrix C1 = 
051                        Matrix.makeRealMatrix(3, 3,
052                                        0.0,  0.0, 2, 
053                                        0.0, -1.0, 0.0, 
054                                        2,    0.0, 0.0);
055        
056        private static final RealMatrix C1i = 
057                        Matrix.makeRealMatrix(3, 3,
058                                        0.0,  0.0, 0.5, 
059                                        0.0, -1.0, 0.0, 
060                                        0.5,  0.0, 0.0);
061        
062        private final double[] q;       // = (A,B,C,D,E,F) ellipse parameters
063        
064        public EllipseFitFitzgibbonStable(Pnt2d[] points, Pnt2d xref) {
065                this.q = fit(points, xref);
066        }
067        
068        public EllipseFitFitzgibbonStable(Pnt2d[] points) {
069                this(points, PntUtils.centroid(points));
070        }
071
072        @Override
073        public double[] getParameters() {
074                return this.q;
075        }
076        
077        private double[] fit(Pnt2d[] points, Pnt2d xref) {
078                final int n = points.length;
079                if (n < 5) {
080                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("fitter requires at least 5 sample points instead of " + points.length);
081                }
082
083                // reference point
084                final double xr = xref.getX();
085                final double yr = xref.getY();
086
087                RealMatrix X1 = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(n, 3);
088                RealMatrix X2 = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(n, 3);
089                
090                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
091                        final double x = points[i].getX() - xr; // center data set
092                        final double y = points[i].getY() - yr;
093                        double[] f1 = {sqr(x), x*y, sqr(y)};
094                        double[] f2 = {x, y, 1};
095                        X1.setRow(i, f1);
096                        X2.setRow(i, f2);
097                }
098
099                // build reduced scatter matrices:
100                RealMatrix S1 = X1.transpose().multiply(X1);
101                RealMatrix S2 = X1.transpose().multiply(X2);
102                RealMatrix S3 = X2.transpose().multiply(X2);            
103                RealMatrix S3i = MatrixUtils.inverse(S3);
104                
105                RealMatrix T = S3i.scalarMultiply(-1).multiply(S2.transpose());         
106                RealMatrix Z = C1i.multiply(S1.add(S2.multiply(T)));
107                
108                // find the eigenvector of Z which satisfies the ellipse constraint:
109//              EigenDecomposition ed = new EigenDecomposition(Z);
110                EigenDecompositionJama ed = new EigenDecompositionJama(Z);
111                double[] p1 = null;
112                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
113                        RealVector e = ed.getEigenvector(i);
114                        if (e.dotProduct(C1.operate(e)) > 0) {
115                                p1 = e.toArray();
116                                break;
117                        }
118                }
119                
120                if (p1 == null) {
121                        IJ.log("p1 is null! " + Arrays.toString(points));
122                        return null;
123                }
124                
125                double[] p2 = T.operate(p1);
126                
127                RealMatrix U = getDataOffsetCorrectionMatrix(xr, yr);
128                
129                // assemble q
130                return U.operate(Matrix.join(p1, p2));
131        }
132        
133}
